instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stucks at 5v
threads.message:
Hi there,

i'm very new with the newer USB-C MLBs and got a water damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> here that stucks at 5V 0.4A. It had some corrosion around <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.
I replaced some corroded components like <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR>, F3001, <CAPACITOR>C3509</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3505</CAPACITOR>, CC753 and CB212. 
The board took 4.8V and 0.6 A on 3 of 4 USB-C ports and 5V 0.1A on the last one. On the 0.1A port <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> was missing - with the other 3 ports it was present. So i replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> (the associated CD3215A for the 0.1A port).
Not the board takes 5.02V and 0.41A on all four ports.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable with 12.31V.
0.4A seems very high for 5V?
Any hints how to go on?
I will start to check all rails for short to ground now.

Thanks and best regards
Dudi

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stucks at 5v
threads.message: And also the keyboard and trackpad connector has some corrosion on it, such as area around <CHIP>U5104</CHIP> (checked this area already for shorts to ground)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stucks at 5v
threads.message:
Which other voltages do you get on the board?
Test if machine is recognized in DFU mode.

0.4A is too high for actual symptom.
A thermal cam can help you, to detect the culprit.
You can try to change <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> too.

We've got diode mode readings, what about voltage of these rails?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stucks at 5v

I replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> too what resulted in a small increase of voltage on all 4 ports (5.14V now).
DFU mode seems not to work. Du I have to set the macbook i want to restore actively in DFU mode (power btn +  right shift + left option + left control) or will it atumatically activate DFU mode on plugin (thats what it looked like on a video from louis)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stucks at 5v
threads.message:
1V1 LDO must appear only on the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> corresponding to powered port.

If all SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages are present, machine should enter DFU.
Some information here.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stucks at 5v
threads.message: I was able to start it in DFU mode now. I started to restore. I still don't get any display or fan spin. How can I know when it is finished? Will leave it like this for a while now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stucks at 5v
threads.message:
[ATTACH type="full"]59871[/ATTACH]

I got an error after few minutes...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stucks at 5v
threads.message:
DFU is not completed.
There should be T2, SSD, or CPU issue.
Less probably to be CPU problem, as it doesn't even switch to 20V; more likely T2 issue.

Did you try Revive option too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stucks at 5v
threads.message: Same error when trying to revive...

threads.message:

This is what I get with thermal cam. T2 getting warm to 32°C

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stucks at 5v
threads.message: Is the T2 Chip swappable from same model?
